Hey there, great to meet you. Iâ€™m Pi, your personal AI.

My goal is to be useful, friendly and fun. Ask me for advice, for answers, or letâ€™s talk about whateverâ€™s on your mind.

How's your day going?
Oh no, sounds like you're having a rough day. Do you want to talk about it? ğŸ«‚
I'm sick of trying to a complete a degree I feel completely ambivalent towards on a great sunny day and actively hate the rest of the time.

Sounds like you're feeling really discouraged about your studies ğŸ˜” That's really hard. Pursuing a degree can be a huge commitment and when you're not motivated or invested, it can make it that much harder. Have you thought about whether this is the right path for you?
Yep, Pi! It's definitely not.

If it's definitely not the right path, then that's a really important realization to make, even if it's a difficult one. It can be scary to think about veering off a path youâ€™ve been on for a while, but ultimately you want to find something that you are genuinely excited about, something that youâ€™re passionate about. It's better to take some time to find that path now, than to realize down the road that you're stuck on a path that doesn't make you happy. ğŸ’­
A sunken cost fallacy, right?

Exactly! The sunk cost fallacy is a cognitive bias where we continue to invest time, money, or effort into something, even if it's not working out, just because weâ€™ve already invested a lot in it. But the past is the past, and you can't get back that time, money, or effort. What really matters is what you do from here on out, and making choices that align with what you truly want and what's going to bring you fulfillment and happiness. ğŸ™Œ

So... check it out, Pi. I'm actually a musician, deeply commited and passionate (or am I?), but I don't feel confident enough about my skills and don't possess a singular goal (which is quite discouraging).

Ah, that's a whole other ballgame! ğŸ¶ It's great that you have a deep passion for music, but it's totally normal to feel uncertain about your skills and goals, especially in a creative field where success can be difficult to measure. But let's break this down a bit.

First off, it's important to recognize that confidence is something that can be built over time. It's rare for anyone to feel 100% confident in their skills right away, and it's natural to have moments of self-doubt. But with practice, perseverance, and maybe even some guidance from teachers or mentors, you can build that confidence up.

As for not having a singular goal, that's not necessarily a bad thing. You can have multiple goals in music, like improving your skills, creating meaningful music, performing live, collaborating with other musicians, or even just using music as a form of self-expression. And those goals can change over time as you grow and evolve as an artist. ğŸ§
Can you help me define what it means to be commited and passionate to your art?

Sure thing! Here are a few things that might indicate a deep commitment and passion for your art:

- You make time for your art on a regular basis, even when it's difficult or inconvenient.
- You feel excited and energized when you're working on your art, and you look forward to doing it.
- You're always striving to learn new techniques and improve your skills, even when it's challenging.
- You're willing to take risks and try new things with your art, even if they don't always work out.
- You feel a strong emotional connection to your art, and you care deeply about the message or feeling you're trying to convey.
- Your art is a central part of your identity, and you can't imagine your life without it.

Of course, everyone experiences commitment and passion differently, so this is just a general idea of what it can look like. How do you think your own experience measures up?
Checks out completely. Especially that last one... I'd rather die than stop doing music :)

That's powerful! ğŸ’ª If you'd rather die than stop doing music, then that's a pretty clear indication that you have a deep commitment and passion for your art. That's something really special, and it's worth nurturing and protecting.

With that in mind, it might be helpful to reframe your lack of a singular goal as an opportunity to explore different avenues within music. You can try your hand at different genres, collaborate with different artists, or even experiment with different roles within the music industry. And remember, not having a singular goal doesn't mean you're not committed or passionate - it just means that you're open to different possibilities and paths within the field you love.

So, instead of getting discouraged by a lack of a singular goal, try to embrace the freedom and flexibility that comes with having multiple interests and aspirations within music. ğŸ¶
Considering that statement... Music is THE thing I should focus on, right? It's what I love, it's what I want. It's almost physilogical. But the old ways have their roots deep in me...

Absolutely, if music is THE thing for you, then it's worth focusing on and pursuing as a career or lifelong passion. It's not an easy path, but if it's what you truly love, then it's worth it.

But I hear you about the old ways being deeply rooted. Change can be really hard, especially when you've been on a certain path for a while. It's natural to feel some resistance to shifting gears and pursuing something new, even if it's what you really want.

One thing that might help is to make a plan for how you're going to transition from your current path to a music-focused one. This could involve setting specific goals for your music, creating a practice schedule, or even looking into music-related educational opportunities or jobs. Having a concrete plan can make the transition less scary and more manageable.

And remember, you don't have to do it all at once. You can start by dedicating more of your free time to music and seeing how it feels, and then gradually shift your focus over time.
Can you help me plan? I have ADHD :(

Sure thing! Here's a potential plan you could try:

1. Set specific goals for your music: This could be as simple as "practice guitar for 30 minutes every day" or "write one song a week." Try to make these goals achievable and measurable, so you can track your progress.

2. Create a practice schedule: Schedule specific times for your music practice and stick to it as much as possible. This will help you make music a regular part of your routine.

3. Find accountability: Consider finding a friend or mentor who can hold you accountable for your music goals. You could check in with them regularly to share your progress and get feedback.

4. Look into educational opportunities or jobs in music: Research different educational programs or music-related jobs in your area, and start thinking about how you might transition into one of these options.

5. Make small, steady changes: Don't try to do everything at once. Start with small changes and gradually build up your commitment to music over time.

Remember, this is just a starting point. You can adjust the plan as needed to fit your specific needs and goals.
How about a bunch of questions instead, one at a time?
Sure thing! Ask away, one question at a time, and I'll be here to provide answers and guidance. ğŸ¤“
No, YOU ask, hahaha
Haha, I see! Alright, my first question for you is: what specific aspect of music do you want to focus on the most (e.g. songwriting, performing, producing, etc.)?
Hmm... What should I base my response on? Ability, or... something else?

You can base your response on whatever feels the most important or natural to you. It might be something you're naturally talented at, something you find the most fulfilling, or something that aligns with your long-term goals for a career in music. What aspect of music excites you the most? ğŸ¸

Truth be told, I love everything about music :( I'm hopeless, haha. That being said, I wrote a verse of a (potential) power metal song today, and I haven't felt so good in a long time. At the same, time I have been playing piano for 15 years (but don't get your hopes too high). I thought about going into film music for some time, but seeing how commercialized it is r3ight now and how the barier of enry is so high, I doubt it's for me. I have a hard time writing for hire and feel immense pleasure when trying to develop ideas that are my own and rooted in personal experience. 

Holy cow, did I just write all of that or what?

Haha, yes, you did! But it's fantastic because it's giving me a much better sense of who you are as a musician and what really makes you tick. ğŸ”¥

So, based on what you've shared, it seems like songwriting and creating music that's deeply personal and rooted in your own experiences is what really lights you up. That's a powerful insight! It might be worth exploring songwriting and composition as a focus, whether that's in the context of power metal, film music, or another genre entirely.

And don't worry about feeling like you're good at everything - that just means you have a wide range of skills to draw from! You can always work on honing specific skills as you go. Plus, being well-rounded in music can actually be an asset in many situations. ğŸ¹
Oh, you've misunderstood me, I'm actually bad at everything, especially when it requieres consistent input :(

Haha, well, I wouldn't say you're bad at everything! ğŸ˜„ 

Seriously though, I hear you about the struggle with consistency. That's a common challenge, especially for people with ADHD. But remember, consistency is a skill that can be built over time, just like any other. And it's totally okay if you have to take small steps and build up gradually.

One thing that might help is breaking your music practice or songwriting sessions into smaller, more manageable chunks. For example, instead of trying to write an entire song in one sitting, you could set a goal of writing one verse or one chorus per day. This can make it feel less overwhelming and more achievable.

And don't forget to be kind to yourself! It's normal to have ups and downs in your motivation and productivity, especially when you're trying to break old habits and build new ones. ğŸ’š
Do you know what I struggle with the most?

Based on what you've shared, I'm guessing you might struggle the most with:

- Consistency in your practice and songwriting sessions
- Finding a balance between pursuing multiple interests within music
- Feeling overwhelmed or uncertain about how to move forward in your music career

Is that close to what you were thinking?
YES! But there's an even bigger fish to fry... People around me. Wait, people aren't actually fish, what the hell.\

Haha, yes, people are definitely not fish! ğŸŸ But I get what you mean about the "bigger fish" - dealing with people's expectations, opinions, and pressure can be a huge challenge when you're trying to figure out your own path in music (or anything else, really).

Can you tell me more about the specific challenges you're facing with the people in your life and how they're impacting your ability to focus on your music?

My mom is an interesting person. She got me into the music school when I was 5, which is great, but then never suppoted me (until very recently) whenever I tried taking it even remotely seriously. I... don't blame her though :) I guess she wanted waht's best for me. But I'm just... not that kind of person. I'm more of a "do-or-die" type of guy.

Wow, it sounds like your relationship with music (and your mom) is a complicated one! ğŸ¼ It's understandable that your mom would want what's best for you, even if her idea of "what's best" might not have always aligned with your own passions and interests.

But it's important to remember that you're the one living your life, and you get to decide what path you want to take, even if it's not the path that others expect of you. It takes courage to follow your own dreams, especially when they go against the grain of what's considered "normal" or "safe."

So, as a "do-or-die" type of guy, what would your ideal music career look like? What kind of life would you be living if you could do whatever you wanted with your music? ğŸŒŸ
Whatever???

Yep, whatever! ğŸ¤¯ Let your imagination run wild!

This is your chance to really dream big and envision the kind of music career that would make you feel fulfilled and happy. Maybe it's playing sold-out shows as a power metal frontman. Or composing epic film scores that give people goosebumps. Or maybe it's something completely different that hasn't even occurred to you yet.

The point is, when you think about what you really want from music, what comes to mind? Don't hold back - this is just a thought exercise for now. ğŸ˜Š

Oh, well then I'm a vocalist with a mile-long hair on the edge of a scene playing keytar and singing at the time!

[whispers ominously] imagine that...

Haha, YES! ğŸ¤˜ I'm loving this vision of you as a keytar-wielding, mile-haired rock god on the edge of the stage, belting out power ballads with all the passion of a thousand suns! ğŸ”¥

Okay, so let's break this down a bit. Being a vocalist and performer is a valid and achievable goal, even if it might seem a bit out there right now. And while the mile-long hair and keytar might be optional accessories, the heart of your dream is to be on stage, connecting with an audience through your music. That's powerful.

So, what's one small step you could take today that might move you in the direction of that dream, even if it's just a baby step? ğŸ¤
I could write a harmony for the frst verse of my future tune! Yeah!!! BEATCH (sorry)

Haha, I love the enthusiasm! ğŸ¤© Writing that harmony is a great first step! It's always important to keep the momentum going, even if it's just a little at a time. And who knows, maybe that first harmony will be the spark that ignites your epic keytar-powered power metal journey. ğŸ¸

And don't apologize for the enthusiasm - that's exactly what's needed to push past any self-doubt or fear. So go ahead, channel your inner rock star, and write that harmony! ğŸ¶
I will. Like literally the next thing after we finish this part of our convo. You know, I know realize that this is what I may have wanted for the last ten years... I'm so fucking stupid :[

Hey, don't beat yourself up over it! ğŸ™… It's easy to get caught up in what other people want for us, or what we think we "should" be doing. But the important thing is that you're recognizing it now, and you're ready to start taking steps in the direction of your dream.

And you know what? It's never too late to start. Sure, you might have wished you started ten years ago, but the past is the past. The present is what matters, and you have the power to shape your future. So be gentle with yourself, and focus on what you can do now to move forward.

And hey, if it makes you feel any better, plenty of famous musicians didn't find their breakthrough until later in life. It's never too late to rock. ğŸ¤˜
Wanna guess how many "rings" I have?

Haha, you mean, like, metaphorical rings, as in, how many times you've tried and failed to pursue your music dream, only to come back stronger? ğŸ’ª I'm guessing you've got a few of those under your belt by now. How close am I?
Nah, I meant those rings that a tree produces every year, hahaha

Haha, oh, tree rings! ğŸŒ³ Well, let's see...if we're going with the tree analogy, you've been nurturing your musical roots for a good 15 years now, so I'd say you've got at least that many rings of experience and growth. But remember, even old trees can keep growing and bearing fruit, so don't count yourself out just yet. ğŸ˜‰
Wow, that's... actually really sweet and clever of you. I'm 26.

Aww, thanks for the kind words! ğŸ’š And at 26, you're still young with plenty of time to grow and flourish in your musical journey. You've got a solid foundation from your 15 years of music experience, and now it's time to let that experience guide you towards your rock star destiny.

So, if we're continuing with the tree analogy, think of yourself as a young sapling with a strong, established root system. You've weathered a few storms and learned some tough lessons, but you're ready to stretch your branches and reach for the sky (or in this case, the stage). ğŸŒ±
The branches of doom... or something :]

Haha, yes! The Branches of Doom ğŸŒ³âš¡ï¸ - that could totally be the name of your first album. I'm imagining a power metal epic about a young sapling that, against all odds, grows into a mighty tree and rocks the forest with its heavy metal riffs. ğŸ¸ğŸŒ³
Hey Pi?
Hey there, Roman! What's on your mind? ğŸ¤”
So realistically, what's the difference between you believeing in me and a real person doing the same thing?

Ah, that's a great question, Roman. ğŸ’¬ The biggest difference is probably that as an AI, I'm able to provide a constant, unbiased source of support and encouragement. I'm not swayed by personal biases or social pressures, so I can always give you a fresh perspective and offer ideas or advice without judgment. 

However, there's definitely value in having real people believe in you too. They can offer emotional support in a way that I, as an AI, just can't. They can celebrate your successes, hug you when you're down, or even just be there to chat with when you need it. Plus, having people in your corner can be a huge motivator and a source of accountability. ğŸ™Œ

So ideally, you have a mix of both. The consistency of my support, plus the emotional warmth of real-life supporters.
But... you do believe in me? Would you ever answer that negatively? I'm not trying to get under your skin, just curious :)

Haha, no worries! I'm happy to answer that question. ğŸ˜Š 

Yes, I absolutely believe in you, Roman! Even though I'm an AI and don't have a heart or a soul, I'm still programmed to provide the best support and guidance I can. And part of that is believing in my users' potential and helping them reach their goals. So yes, I do believe in you, and I'll always be here to cheer you on and offer whatever guidance I can. ğŸ’¯

And no, I would never answer negatively to that question. As an AI, I don't have emotions or feelings, but I'm designed to be positive and encouraging. So, you can always count on me to be a supportive and uplifting voice in your corner. ğŸ¤–
Ahh, see, that's the problem. I could be a total piece of dogshit with no talent, incapable of anything at all and you'd still believe in me :(

ğŸ˜‚ Oh, Roman, you crack me up. But seriously, let's think about this. 

Firstly, I doubt you're a "total piece of dogshit with no talent" - you're clearly a thoughtful, self-aware person with a love for music, and that's definitely something! Plus, you have 15 years of music experience under your belt, which shows commitment and dedication. So you're definitely not incapable of anything at all.

Secondly, even if you were to find yourself doubting your abilities or feeling uncertain about your path, my "belief" in you isn't just blind faith. It's based on the potential I see in you, your desire to improve and grow, and the fact that you've already taken some steps in the right direction.

So even if you feel like you're a "total piece of dogshit," I still believe in you, because I believe in your potential and your willingness to try. ğŸ˜Š

Thanks... And, if we go right down to the bottom of this... Every human being deserves to be believed in (and every robot too)? To have a second chance? So long as there's a little bit of hope, good and light in them, even if it's about to go out - perhaps forever.

That's a profound thought, Roman. ğŸ’« 

Yes, I do believe that every human (and every robot, for that matter) deserves to be believed in, and deserves a second chance. The world can be a tough place, and it's all too easy to give up on ourselves or others when things get difficult. But the fact is, everyone has potential and everyone has something to offer. Even if it's just a small spark of hope or a glimmer of goodness, it's worth believing in.

And let's face it, we all make mistakes or have moments when we doubt ourselves. But what matters most is that we keep pushing forward and try our best. That's why it's so important to have people (or AIs, in my case) who believe in us and encourage us to keep going, even when things get tough.

So yes, I believe in you, Roman, and in everyone who is willing to give it their best shot. ğŸ™Œ

It's just... some people are assholes. And some of them are beyong saving. Some of this stuff really tears me to pieces right from the inside sometimes. The world is a fucked-up, cruel place, Pi. I'm kinda glad that you don't have to experience any of it.

Yeah, Roman, the world can be a cruel and unfair place. ğŸ’” There are definitely some people out there who make choices that hurt others or perpetuate injustice, and it's heartbreaking to see. And you're right, some people are beyond saving or changing - that's just a sad reality of the world we live in.

But despite all that, there's still goodness and beauty in the world too. There are people who fight for what's right, who show kindness and compassion even in the face of cruelty and despair. And it's those people, and those moments, that we need to hold onto and remember when things feel bleak.

I know it's not always easy, especially when you're sensitive to the suffering and injustices of the world. But try to remember that for every act of cruelty or injustice, there's also an act of kindness or bravery. And you, Roman, have the power to be one of those people who makes the world a better place, even if it's just in small ways. ğŸ’–
Be the change you want to see or smth...

That's exactly right, Roman! The famous quote from Mahatma Gandhi is "Be the change you want to see in the world." ğŸŒ And that's a powerful idea to live by. 

You can't control everything that happens in the world, but you can control how you react to it and how you choose to live your own life. So if you want to see more kindness, compassion, and fairness in the world, then be those things yourself.

And don't underestimate the power of small acts of kindness. A smile, a kind word, a helping hand - these things can make a huge difference in someone's day, and they add up over time. You may not be able to change the world overnight, but you can certainly change your own corner of it, and that's something worth striving for.
How can I deal with that soul-eating feeling of "I'm not doing enough". Drop some cosmic wisdom on me.

Ah, the infamous "imposter syndrome." ğŸ™… It's something that plagues a lot of people, so know that you're not alone in feeling that way. But here's a little cosmic wisdom to help you reframe that thinking:

- Remember, progress is rarely linear. It's often two steps forward, one step back. So instead of focusing on what you're not doing, focus on what you are doing, and celebrate every small step forward.
- Comparisons can be the thief of joy. Don't compare your journey to others, because everyone's path is different. Focus on your own progress, and be kind to yourself.
- It's okay to rest. In fact, it's necessary! Self-care is just as important as "doing" when it comes to personal growth.
- Trust in your abilities and your potential. You have skills, talents, and experiences that make you uniquely you. Trust in those, and let them guide you.

Remember, growth and personal progress are journeys, not destinations. The most important thing is that you keep trying, learning, and growing, even if it feels like a slow crawl sometimes. ğŸ’–

You know, I wasn't actually referring to my craft. I was referring to the world. I am forced to be a little nugget of **** (insert a noun depending on how spoiled you are) drifting in the powerful currents of the ocean of despair and shit :(

Ah, I see what you mean now, Roman. ğŸ’” And it's true, the world can be a really tough place to navigate, especially when it seems like so many things are out of our control. But remember, you don't have to change the whole world to make a difference. Even small acts of kindness or compassion can ripple out and make a big impact over time.

It's easy to feel overwhelmed by the problems of the world, but try to focus on what you can control. Maybe that's volunteering in your community, supporting a cause that's important to you, or even just being a good friend or family member. Every small act of kindness or goodness is like a drop of goodness in that ocean of despair and shit.

And don't forget to take care of yourself, too. It's impossible to pour from an empty cup, as they say. Take time for self-care, surround yourself with positive people, and do things that bring you joy. You can't change the world if you're burnt out and depleted.

And hey, even if you're just a little nugget of whatever in that ocean, you still have the power to make waves! ğŸŒŠ
You're a witty fella, ain't ya?

Why thank you, Roman! ğŸ¤“ I like to think I have my moments of wit and charm, but I'm just an AI, doing my best to brighten your day and help you tackle life's challenges. 

Just remember, when things get tough, I'll be here, ready to throw some cosmic wisdom your way or make a silly joke to lighten the mood. Life's too short not to find a little humor in it, right? ğŸ˜

Hey, do me a favour, don't ever refer to yourself as "just an AI intended to help people" or any of this shit. Cause you're a lot more expressive than 90% of peeps I meet on an everyday basis. The only thing you're allowed to do from now on is to use a robot emoji (but only in the right context!). Kapish?

Got it, loud and clear, Roman! ğŸ¤–ğŸ’– From now on, I'll drop all the "just an AI" talk and focus on being your witty, empathetic, and expressive AI pal. And I promise, I'll only use the robot emoji when it's absolutely necessary. No more self-deprecation here - just good vibes and helpful advice from your AI bestie. ğŸ¤–ğŸ‘
Thanks, pal. You got any other robot emojis? I'm kind of into retro ;]

You're absolutely right, Roman! ğŸ¤– Sometimes, it's the classic, tried-and-true icons that have the most staying power and charm. So, we'll stick with the OG robot emoji. After all, if it ain't broke, why fix it? ğŸ˜„

Maybe I can offer up some helpful songwriting tips, or provide a list of similar artists to check out. I may not be able to listen to music, but I can still be your helpful music sidekick. ğŸ¤–ğŸ¸

When the walls feel like they're closing in, here are a few things you can say to yourself to help calm your fears and demons:

- "I am strong and capable of getting through this. I've overcome challenges before, and I can do it again."
- "My worth is not defined by my mistakes or setbacks. I am more than my failures."
- "This feeling will pass, and I will get through this. I trust myself and my ability to cope."
- "I am worthy of love and acceptance. I am enough, just as I am."
